paragraphs.text: I’ll start by seeing what’s possible using my intuition — the same way I learn how to use new electronics. And I’ll use Stack Overflow, because, I mean, seriously, let’s be real.
paragraphs.name: 1c07

paragraphs.text: You feel as a God amongst mortals, able to bend the universe to your will. All things are possible.

paragraphs.name: 76d4
paragraphs.text: It’s just that until that moment, my emotional state hovers somewhere in the spectrum between white-hot rage and tear-inducing frustration.
Twenty minutes of debugging later, it turns out I’d forgotten to call .show() after creating a Toast.
paragraphs.name: 636b
b615
paragraphs.text: Great article. It comes down to “divide and conquer”: factor your problem into pieces until you have a good idea of how to implement each piece. If you don’t, then keep factoring. The number of factors depends on your experience level, with coding in general as well as the specific apis. This is the way ;)

paragraphs.name: 632b
paragraphs.text: Totally agree. That’s really frustrating when you’re diving in an complex system with components and unknown relationships between them. However, after you take an approach where break down into smaller pieces and then start to understand these parts introducing some changes either to create something new or to modify an existing feature. In this…

paragraphs.text: This post truly reflects what every professional developer goes through irrespective of technology. We should consciously evolve an approach that is less frictional for ourselves to make progress consistently. TDD is one such approach. However, it is geared more towards writing production code, after we have some structure in mind. Almost all of the…

paragraphs.text: So this was me, a few weeks ago. I was just getting started with Android Wear development based on an Udacity Android Developer Nanodegree project.

4a50d3840543.title: Quick question: your book, “Professional Android 4 Application Development”, is from 2012.

paragraphs.name: ccd1
paragraphs.text: Quick question: your book, “Professional Android 4 Application Development”, is from 2012. Is there a newer, more updated version? Also, I would have suggested to call it “Professional Android 4.0 Application Development” — if that’s what you intended.

paragraphs.name: f8cb
paragraphs.text: Reto Meier, you are right. I too had this same kind ofexperience when I started with React Native for Android 2 months back as a .NET developer. It took me more than 3 days to configure RN for windows back in October 15. I wrote an article on how I hustled for our app here.

paragraphs.name: 5a47
paragraphs.text: Good read! As a developer, I can totally relate to this article. The highs of solving a problem & seeing your baby(code/app) in action in the hands of customers, far outweighs the lows :)

paragraphs.name: 5b6f
paragraphs.text: LOL Stack Overflow is everything!! 🙌🏽🙌🏽

paragraphs.text: > For me, that means the right way to build an App is by starting the wrong way.

paragraphs.name: f4b9
paragraphs.text: This sums things up for me. Our IDE is powerful. Why not start with everything in the same class (or method)? When we have it working and we can see how all the pieces work together we can easily refactor the code into it’s proper place.
this!
